MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Travellers' Social Welfare Claims.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the present arrangements for signing on to claim unemployment benefit/assistance by travellers; and the changes which have recently been made affecting travellers who have heretofore been signing at their local exchange at 11.30 a.m. on Thursday.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The social welfare legislation provides that all applicants for unemployment benefit and unemployment assistance must be available for, capable of and genuinely seeking work. In order to satisfy the Department that they satisfy these statutory conditions, claimants are required to attend their local office or signing centre, normally once a week, and sign a declaration that they are unemployed.

MainHeading.P: Special signing arrangements exist for persons of no fixed abode throughout the country, all of whom are required to attend at their local office at the same time every week: Thursday mornings between 11.30 and 12. This arrangement, which was established in 1981, applies to all persons of no fixed abode, who are mainly from the travelling community. It is not normally applicable in the case of travellers who are known to have settled and have permanent addresses.

There has been no change in these administrative arrangements. However, following a recent meeting with the monitoring committee for travelling people, my Department has undertaken a review of travellers applicants who attend at the Gardiner St. and Werburgh St. employment exchanges to identify settled travellers with permanent addresses with a view to intergrating them into the normal signing arrangements generally applied to persons with fixed addresses. Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: I can answer the Deputy's question only in relation to agencies under the aegis of my Department or agencies in receipt of State funding through my Department. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Meat Distribution.

Qst.Quest: if he is satisfied with the manner in which meat is distributed from vans by meat wholesalers to retailers and small butchers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: The Food Hygiene (Amendment) Regulations, 1989, (S.I. No. 62 of 1989) introduced stringent controls on the transport of foods in food vehicles and several of the provisions relate specifically to the handling and transport of meat.

In addition to the general requirements of structural and operational hygiene laid down for all food vehicles, vehicles used for the conveyance of meat must comply with the following provisions: the vehicles must display the words “meat vehicle” in letters at least 7.5 cm in height in a prominent position on the vehicle; the vehicle must not be used for any other purpose other than the transport of meat and meat products; food workers involved in the conveyance of meat must wear suitable apparel including covering for head, neck and shoulders when carcases, half carcases of quarters are being handled; all meat in carcases, half carcases or quarters must not be conveyed in a food vehicle unless it bears a health mark prescribed by the Minister for Agriculture and Food in accordance with the provisions of section 40 of the Abattoirs Act, 1988 (No. 8 of 1988); where cooked and uncooked meats are transported in the same food vehicle care must be taken to avoid cross contamination; and meat that is transported between an abattoir and a butcher's shop over a distance exceeding five miles must be transported at a specified temperature.

MainHeading.P: I am satisfied that these provisions of the food hygiene regulations on the transport of meat provide health boards with effective controls for ensuring that meat distributed from vans by meat wholesalers to retailers and small butchers is fit for human consumption.

As regards the question of the reconstruction and refurbishment of the Deverill Place building I would refer the Deputy to my reply to his parliamentary question on 15 February 1990.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Wexford School Project.

Qst.Quest: the present position regarding funding for a school (details supplied) in County Wexford.
the reason for the delay in the extension of a primary school (details supplied) in County Wexford; when work will commence; and if she will expedite the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 169 and 171 together.

Tenders for the proposed extension to the National School in Co. Wexford referred to have been forwarded by the school authorities to my Department and have been examined. A number of points in relation to the project had to be clarified and these were fully discussed with the school authorities and their consultants at a meeting in my Department last week. I am not in a position, at this stage, to say when building works will commence.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Kildare School Teacher Numbers.

Qst.Quest: the total number of teachers allocated to Kildare Vocational Education Committee for the year 1989-1990; the total number of teachers involved under each subject heading; if any subjects are being taught in Kildare Vocational Education Committee schools in respect of which no specific teacher allocation has been made; if subjects have been dropped; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The Deputy will appreciate that it would not be appropriate for me to disclose details of a VEC's allocation of teaching staff, as requested, as these matters are confidential between the VEC and my Department.

The question of the utilisation of VEC's teacher allocation under the various subject headings is a matter for the Chief Executive Officer and the committee in consultation with the principal teachers in the different schools within the scheme.

My Department has, in the past few days, received from County Kildare VEC an appeal against its teacher allocation for the current school session, 1989-90, and this appeal is currently under consideration by my Department.

Qst.Quest: the number of commissioned reports which he is currently awaiting from committees, commissions, inter-departmental committees and working groups.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: I am awaiting reports from two working groups namely: working group to review the Road Transport Act, 1932; and working group to consider the options of light rail and busway in relation to the former Harcourt Street railway line and between Tallaght and the city centre.
I will also be getting further reports from the inter-departmental committee to review access to road and rail transport for mobility handicapped persons which to date has furnished two reports.
Further information on these bodies is contained in my reply to Question No. 310 of 20 February 1990.
